Colleagues, at this time we will open the remote public comment period for items on the city council agenda, Introducion and referral calendar, and ongoing.
It remains a strong intent of the city Council to have remote public comment regularly included on meeting Agendas.
However as a reminder, the city council removes the right to end or remove if the system is being abused or no longer suitable for allowing our meeting to be conducted efficiently and effectively.
I'll moderate the public comment period in the following manner.
Today's public comment period is slated to last 20 minutes.
We do have a significant number of individuals who are signed up to provide public comment today.
So, I am going to go ahead and extend public comment period by 10 minutes for a total of 30 minutes.
So, colleagues, if there is no objection, the public comment period will be extended to last a total of 30 minutes.
Hearing no objection, the public comment period is extended to last 30 minutes.
In an effort to hear from as many folks in that 30 minutes I am going to have to reduce the amount of time allotted to each Speaker.
Instead of having two minutes each, every Speaker will be provided a total of one minute to address the city council this afternoon.
Speakers are called upon in the order in which they registered to provide public comment on the Council's Website.
Each Speaker must call in from the phone number used for this registration and using the meeting, phone number and Passcode that was Emailed to them upon confirmation.
This is different than the general meeting lesson line call in information.
Again, I'll call on each Speaker by name, and in the order in which they registered on the Website.
If you have not yet registered to speak but would like to, you can sign up before the end of public comment by going to the Website at Seattle.Gov/Counsel.
The public comment link is also listed on today's agenda.
Once I call your name, staff will Unmute your microphone and you will hear a automatic prompt that you have been Un-Muted.
This will be your Cue to press Star six before you begin speaking.

Please begin by stating your name, the item that you are addressing, and as a reminder, public comment should relate to an item on today's agenda, the introduction and referral calendar, or the Council's work program.
Speakers will hear a time when 10 seconds I left of the allotted time.
Once you hear the Chime, please begin wrapping up your public comment.
If you do not end your comment at the end of the allotted time provided, your microphone will be needed to allow us to call on the neck Speaker.
Once you've completed your public comment we ask that you please Disconnect from the line.
If you plan to continue following this meeting you can do so by watching us on Seattle Channel, or anyone of the listing options listed on the agenda.
The public comment period is now open.
It is about 2:15 P.M.
We will go until about 2:45 P.M.
We will begin with the first Speaker on the list.
Again come after you press--after you hear you have been Un- muted, press Star six so you can Unmute yourself.
The Firstperson is Howard followed by aerial.
Hi.
On May 19, 2020, the SPD murdered a man.

Despite the director being on site shortly after this killing, and the clear Video evidence it was immediately available indicating a profound failure of the escalation, he made a decision not to open a investigation.
It wasn't until August 20th, three months later, that they announced they suddenly found my complaint from June, and were opening an investigation.

This, despite the fact that he took charge of the investigation just weeks after another killing, and then watched as three more people of color in severe mental health crisis, all wielding a knife or no weapon at all were killed by the SPD.
In all cases, they were ruled lawful and proper to last week, the OPA is quote the most robust transparent civilian led system in the United States of America.
It is not debatable.
We have more civilian oversight here than anywhere else.
I have not seen a model that is better than ours.
This is Orwellian and Patently ludicrous.
We must create a true 100% civilian oversight of police.
Please visit Seattle Stop.Org to find out how.
Next up is aerial lapse in.
Followed by Stephanie Ingram.
I'm speaking today to address Councilwoman Sawant's end the deadly exchange the resolution.
I'm truly disappointed to see that Councilwoman Sawant is yet again using totally unrelated International issues to distract from the very real issues we face right here in our city.
Spd and any issues relevant to the city should not be entangled or Conflated with international issues.
This absurd resolution will do nothing for the people that actually live here.
As Councilwoman Sawant points out in her resolution, the Council recently cut $47 million from the SPD budget.
This is a huge and important change, what work as Councilwoman Sawant led to ensure that--this resolution is nothing but political Grandstanding.
The issue of Israel is being invoked because it makes for good media.
Did you notice how Israel is literally the only country she named?
Why?
Because it gets your attention.
It doesn't change anything about life --
Thank you for calling in today.
Next up is Stephanie Ingram followed by Madeleine.

I'm a community member who lives in the central district and I'm an advocate for the community driven Garfield Superblock park renovation project . I support the legislation and hope that some of the Arpa funds will go toward our Superblock project.
Our group has met with staff from the District 3, and we are thrilled that Councilwoman Sawant has agreed to funding.
We urge other Councilmembers to also support this project.
Community engagement led to an idea of an arts and history focused arts renovation.
Have been fighting to make this project a reality ever since.

It is an ambitious project to create a vital civic space in the heart of the central district that honors and tells the story through art and cultural presentations such as the people who live here over the millennia.
The development of a rich community gathering space in the central district is of critical importance to this marginalized neighborhood.
This project aims to honor the role of public space in the area, provide high-quality infrastructure for many you and give the neighborhood --
Thank you for calling in today.
Next up is Madeleine followed by Jared.
Mary, if you are listening, you are showing up as not present on my end.
Please confirm that you are calling into the correct number with the number that you registered with.
Madeleine, welcome.
I am responding to the Arpa funding package.

I just want to emphasize that language is super important when constructing this bill, specifically that the funds be channeled directly into black lives organizations and that the Council use the word black to emphasize the significant contributions that have been made by our local black community.
There are a Plethora of organizations that need this funding . The current white centric Non-Community-Based services do not work for the predominantly black service population.
That is quoting King County equity now.
The Council has an opportunity to set a new precedent by channeling directly into black community.
Instead of indirectly channeling through predominantly white led organizations.
So, changing the channels by which these funds are distributed can prevent from the repetition of the outcome of the paycheck protection program.
So, I just want to emphasize again that language is so important when writing this bill.
Thank you for calling in today.
Next up is Jared Brown followed by George.
Jared, welcome.
Thank you, chair, and Seattle city council.
I live in Seattle in the Lakewood neighborhood and I'm here to discuss the end of the change legislation.
I'm progressive, proud to be liberal and to stand up for those who need help the most.
Coming off June 10th and remembering the tragic deaths of Ronna Taylor, George Floyd and so many others, I agree that police violence often goes too far.
That said, this proposal is not the answer.
On the contrary, it's an affront to progressive liberal, and basic democratic beliefs.
It's ridiculous to imply that learning between the SPD and Israel are the cause of police violence.
Reflecting on Juneteenth undermines the important debate we should instead be having to find proper ways to reduce violence.
Further equating Israel to apartheid is an affront to the black South Africans that lived through the actual apartheid.
Anti-Tran35 rhetoric--which results in violence in our own community.
Thank you for calling in.
Appreciate it.

Followed by Cody.
Lehigh is pleased to support the Council's proposed first tranche of Arpa funding.

As well as private donations.

I'm calling in today to ask the Council to reject Councilmember Sawant's Anti-Tran35 resolution.
It is Factually incorrect, it's unbalanced, it's Disingenuous.
The resolution seeks to somehow Conflate Israel's response to terrorism with policing here in Seattle.
For the record, Israel's training of police forces is, and how to prevent and respond to terrorist attacks, and to save lives.
For example, when the Jewish Federation was attacked a few years back, that would be something that is real would train for and how to respond to that.
It would also be crucial if there were a white Supremacist for example to attack.
Unfortunately Israel is probably the world leader in dealing with terrorism.
So, this strikes me as Anti- Jewish racism to try to falsely Conflate things.
Anti-semitism.
Please oppose it, thank you.

Welcome.

I'm speaking today as the board chair of the Crescent collaborative, a multi- coalition collaborative . We think Council for its focus on a commitment to supporting Bipoc businesses in our historic cultural neighborhood.
But to truly meet the needs of Bipoc small business owners in our neighborhoods, we ask you to Spay special attention to the following.
Funding for businesses should go beyond emergency stopgap funding.
The $5000- $10,000 range that has enabled them to keep their doors open.
What the businesses need now are funds to put them on a solid foundation for reopening economy and strong future.
Consider guidelines that offer funds that provide businesses a measure of economic stability for a more lengthy time.
Potentially up to $100,000.
The second thing is to get funds to businesses quickly and be patient about being payback if payback is required at all.
You've laid a firm ground book for a just and Testable program.
We urge you to keep your eye on the ball and keep it going.
Thank you.

I want to thank Councilmember Herbold as well as Councilmembers Morales and Mosqueda for recognizing and Uplifting the importance and value of our sector and Ecosystems within the amendments that were passed in committee.

I want to emphasize that in addition to driving 18% of Seattle's Ddp, our artists have played a crucial role in interrupting displacement and cultural Erasure and the $3 million dedicated towards arts would go a long way in Jumpstarting a good beginning to a new future for our sector.

For full funding for the Garfield Superblock project.

Finished, this will tell the areas of the central area, lift up the community spiritually and physically and will provide a place for generations to play and relax and celebrate with pride.
The central area is a historically marginalized community as I think many of you know.
The Garfield Superblock is precisely the sort of investment that our community needs to keep the committee healthy.
Weneed a minimum of $5000, $500,000 right now to get us to shovel ready.
We hope that all of you will support it.
Thank you.
Thank you so much for calling in today.
I'm going to go backwards a little bit because I'm showing one of my earlier registered public Commenters is not present.

Has seminar on Israel about preventing terrorism attended several years ago does not change the thousands of decisions made every day at the Seattle police Department.
This unfair resolution ascribes abuse to Israel that is at best misleading and often toxic fiction.
I am the President of the Seattle sister city.
Israel is our political ally, our partner in Congress, as well as our sister city.
This resolution makes people in South Dakota feel unsafe.
There have been many this year.
Threats, beatings and vandalism.

Robert, if you are with us, just remember to press Star six to Unmute yourself.

Afternoon, my name is Robert.
And founder of the Garfield Superblock renovation progress.
Over the past 15 years we have a foundation that has been holding this project down.
Waiting on the city to keep its word.

This project was created through a city ordinance variance for the renovation of Quentin Jones theater and the new Garfield--the mitigating was to work with the community and develop a whole Superblock which included Seattle Garfield Park, interior and exterior.
All I'm asking is for the city to keep its word to this community.
Sometimes it seems like we are forgotten and the promises that have been made so that we can keep our--thank you very much.
Thank you for calling in today.

Lauren, welcome.
I'm born and raised in Seattle and have seen us go through many community issues and problems over the years.
I'm here to just request the Council reject Sawant's resolution to end deadly exchange . I urge you to reject it, the resolution for several reasons, it is not based on fact.
Anyone visiting Israel will see a prosperous Palestinian/Israeli community and not the one that the media represents.

It creates more anti-Semitism in the Seattle city --

I of course suppose the Anti- Semitic resolution by Councilwoman I want to, I want to, and I really hope she gets recalled.

I Emailed Councilmember Strauss about the 2021 Seattle channel appearance.
I would like it if somebody would get a hold of the Seattle channel and tell them to enforce the city of Seattle Video voters guide administrative rules.
Mr. Zimmerman for years abused, his opportunities and thrown Salutes and worse, and I think in order to fight anti-Semitism we need to put a big fat mute on it.
Please enforce the city of Seattle voter guides administrative views.
I Emailed Councilmember Strauss about this.
Thank you, Council President, you're awesome.
Next up is Ariel followed by Naomi.
I'm calling to ask the city Council to reject Councilmember Sawant's Anti-Tran35, and frankly anti-Semitic, run solution and deadly exchange.
Councilwoman Sawant has a history of anti-Semitism and full of lies of resolution, that kind of rhetoric is what is causing the over 500% increase in anti-Semitic attacks around the world.
I may Seattle born and raised woman and Progressive and this kind of racism is unacceptable, especially in a city that I love so much.
I'm hoping that the city council recognizes that Israel has nothing to do with Seattle city police and you are calling out the one and only --
Thank you, Ariel for calling him.
Next up is Naomi followed by Ms. Smith.
Hello.

I just wanted to take a moment today to thank you for including the $20 million in Arpa funds for rapid acquisition and the $2 million for provider capacity and supportive services and permanent supported housing and permanent housing buildings.
The supported housing funds will allow us to deliver critical, critical services for our residents during a time when they are most in need.

The rapid acquisition funds can be leveraged with the state in order to quickly, quickly put buildings Online, which we so desperately need for our lowest income individuals who are most vulnerable during this time.
So, this investment represents an unprecedented level of investment and attention to permanent supportive housing.
We thank you so much for that effort as we all work to continue to develop resources for our community.
Thank you.
Back to so much for calling in, Naomi.
Thank you for the opportunity.
I'm calling really to support a vote that really does Prioritize the most Disproportionally affected.
Particularly, specifically the black community from Covid-19.

As I shared in prior meetings, the black community across nationally, locally, particularly in our city and our County, has suffered immensely and has it not yet received the proper support for the impact of Covid.
So, this particular opportunity needs to be targeted there.
I have read the language.
I do like that the languages specifying those that are disproportionately impacted for organizations that are led and rooted in communities that have been impacted.
I just wanted to be very clear that we do not bypass or use people of color, Bipoc, so that every other community can get the first and the black community still does not see any material effects.
So, please make sure that that is focused, and that you, your leadership --
Thank you so much for calling in today.
Next up is Quinn.
Quinn, welcome.
Thank you so much, president Gonzalez and members of the Council.
I'm speaking today as part of the Garfield community Superblock coalition.
This is a community led coalition, and we are here to support the American rescue plan act legislation that is before the Council.
Hope that some of the funds disbursed will go toward the Garfield Superblock project.
This is not a new project as Mr. Stevens mentioned earlier.
It's creation dates back 15 years and it unfortunately has been continually pushed aside.
This project will honor and tell the story from the Duwamish people to the current African-American and rich tapestry of cultures it is today through a revitalized park in gathering space.
It will lift up the community and create and honor this community.
Thank you so much.
Thank you, Quinn, for taking the time to call in.

By Email.

We are going to go ahead and ship now to other items of business on this afternoon's agenda.

Payment of bills, council bill 120 104 an ordinance appropriating money to pay certain audited claims for the week of June 7th, 2021 through June 11, 2021 and ordering the payment thereof.
Thank you so much, Madame clerk.
I moved to pass Council bill 120104, is there a second?
Second.
It has been moved and Seconded.
Are there any comments?
Hearing none, with the clerk please call the roll on the passage of the bill?

The bill passes and the chair will sign it.
Will the clerk please affix my signature to the legislation on my behalf.
To the clerk please read Adam wanted to the record?

The report of city Council, agenda item 1 Council bill 120102, an ordinance relating to city employment authorizing the execution of a collective bargaining agreement between the city of Seattle and the International brotherhood of electrical workers local 77 to be effective January 23rd, 2021 to January 22, 2023.

Amending ordinance 126237 which adopted the 2021 budget, by increasing appropriations to city light for 2021 payments, therefore and ratifying and confirming certain prior acts, all by a Three-Quarter vote of the city council.
Thank you so much, Madame clerk.
I moved to pass Council bill 120102, is there a second?
Second.
Thank you so much it's been moved and Seconded.
As sponsor of this bill I will address it first and then happy to open the floor to comments from any of the colleagues.

As the title States, council bill 120102 would authorize the execution of a collective bargaining agreement between the city of Seattle and the International brotherhood of electrical workers, local 77.
This collective bargaining agreement is a two year agreement on wages, benefits, hours and other working conditions for a time from January 23rd, 2021 through January 22nd, 2023.
It affects about 565 regularly appointed city employees and its terms include a Cost-Of- living adjustment of 2.5%.

There is also an additional one- time base wage market increase of 10% to certain job titles as listed in attachment a to the collective bargaining agreement and an increase to the Cable Splicer and electrical constructor classifications for parity with the corresponding line worker classification rate of the paper the terms of the collective bargaining agreement to meet the negotiation parameters set by the members of the labor relations polity Committee, of which five members of the city council sit on and participate in actively.

Colleagues, after the labor relations policy committee process, I do as the chair of the labor relations policy Committee on behalf of the city Council, I do recommend that my colleagues support the passage of this legislation.
Are there any additional comments on the bill?
Council member Pedersen.
Thank you, Council President.
Appreciate your hard work on this on the hard work of the members of the labor relations policy committee.

I'm not one of the five Councilmembers serving on the Lrp see, which also includes the Mayor, his executive team, essentially the combined Councilmembers and Mayor's executive team represent management arm of city government.
It negotiates these labor contracts of city government employees.
So, when this proposed project appeared last week it was the first time I was able to review it.
I would like to take this opportunity to explain my vote today to my constituents and how I'm able to get to a Yes vote on this.
First, I want to express my gratitude to our electrical workers who dedicate themselves and their skills to our city.
Thanks again to the hard work of the members of the Lrpc, who members of the public may not know spend hours upon hours outside the spotlight working on all of these labor contracts.
As I understand it, this contract would increase compensation for many of the workers by 12.5%.
Which appear to be unusually high in just one year.
This is an increase of $7.5 million.
Most labor contracts with city government employees recently received an increase based on the consumer price index +1%.
Is 12.5% increase today as I understand it is comprised of the CPI of approximately 2.5 plus another one time 10%.
While the 10% is one time it does create a new baseline of Compensaton for the city employees.
In other words, the higher costs will continue into the second year of the two can't track that's about a $15 million increase.
While this 10% bump is significant, I had the benefit of chairing the committee that includes Seattle city light.
I have additional opportunities to witness the important work conducted by these workers who go out into the field under dangerous conditions to use the skills of their trade to benefit our city.
I understand there has been increased attrition within this group of workers.
Leaving Seattle utility light for other utility enterprises that have been offering compensation at higher levels.
This proposed increase in compensation appears to be an appropriate adjustment to reflect reality spirit this is both public's private sector utilities.
Competing against are fielded skill workers.
City light did also seems to show higher attrition rates among women and people of color.
I hope this increase in compensation can help our utility attract and retain skilled staff to meet its race and gender equity goals.
Another important consideration is how this impact might impact rates.
Utility rates are aggressive with lower income households playing a larger percentage of their household income.
In a city where many of us are concerned about Affordability for our long-term residents, we want to be mindful when increasing costs.

In this case, Seattle city light under the leadership of Deborah Smith has been making so much progress to control other cost drivers that the overall electricity rate increases in their strategic plan have come down.
As we learned in our committee just two weeks ago, our electricity rate increases will average no more than 3.5%, close to the rate of inflation, rather than 4.5% increase previously suggested.
This proposed increase in pay for these highly skilled workers is already built into that 3.5% average rate increase.
In other words, this proposed increase of compensation for these highly skilled professionals will not increase the overall electricity rates further.
Another important consideration is that we are emerging from the pandemic, which should help with overall city revenues.
This is relevant because our general fund takes money from Seattle city light and Seattle public utilities every year with what's called a utility tax.
I'd like to see city government tax on our publicly owned utilities reduced over time to further reduce Regressive rate pressures on low income households.
I appreciate having the past week to review this contract.
I know it's not always possible, but I look forward to an allocation even more time to review labor contracts.
Especially when we are reviewing multiple ones.
This was just one so it was manageable.
Our current Council rules require us to vote yes or no on legislation at full Council, so more time is always welcome to make well-informed decisions.
Thank you for the space to M█Ak these lengthy comments and I will be voting yes.
Not a problem, thank you Councilmember, Pedersen.
Appreciate you digging in and taking a closer look at that.
Okay colleagues, any additional--any other additional comments on the bill?
Hearing none, will the clerk please call the roll on the passage of the bill?
Nine in favor, none opposed.
The bill passes and the chair will sign it.
With the clerk please affect my signature to the legislation on my behalf.
Okay, report of the Finance and housing committee.
With the clerk please read the short title of item 2 into the record.
A report of the Finance and housing Committee, agenda item 2. Council bill 120013.
An ordinance relating--related to the city's response to the Covid-19 crisis creating a new Fund and the city Treasury.
The committee recommends the bill pass as amended.
Payment thank you so much.
Appreciate that, Madame clerk.
Councilmember Mosqueda, you are the chair and I'm going to hand it over to you to provide the reports.
Thank you very much, Madam President.
I am honored to be able to kick off a summary of this legislation that you and I have a chance to co-author together.
Along with the Mayor's office and all the Councilmembers that are here today that provided tremendous input along with community members.
I would do the best to get it kicked off and really just want to thank you I'm excited to be able to be here today as we look to pass the Seattle rescue plan.
I will note that this is the first of three acts that you can expect from us over the next few months.
As we seek to respond to the crisis that Covid not only created, but exacerbated in many cases when you look at the inequities in our previous system that would just explode by Covid.
First of three asked to come.
We have before us with this proposal and the Seattle rescue plan one in front of us, the first tranche of the American rescue plan act dollars.

This represents the first tranche that the city of Seattle is receiving that will total $232 million over the course of this year and next year which means that half of that, $116 million is being passed today.
We are adding to that $12.2 million from the home investment partnership plan.

These bills together, these investments together, represent an incredible opportunity for us to move forward on the commitments that this Council made when we first passed Council resolution 31999 back in March.
Since then we've had five subsequent meetings.
We've had a public hearing completely devoted from hearing from the public about what committee members need and where they would like these dollars Prioritized.
We've had the chance to talk to city councils from Austin to Minneapolis to Denver and so many others to hear where other progressive cities are looking to invest these dollars.

Most importantly, we've heard directly from Community partners, from organizations, from those most impacted by Covid, and from all Councilmembers where you would like to see these dollars invested so that our city money can be coupled with State and Federal investments to truly make an impact now, and to lay the groundwork for a more equitable economy as we seek to recover and respond to Covid.
Two weeks ago we had the chance to introduce this legislation.
Again in partnership with the Council President's office on the Mayor's office, we kept in mind all the recommendations and the priorities that each Councilmember added to the Council resolution.

Since then, we've made sure that among--within our Finance and housing committee members, we've heard from various community members and community--committee Council participants about their priorities.
We had a chance to have discussions about where we would like to see dollars invested so we can address the most urgent needs in our community and lay that more equitable framework.
The priorities we sent to Admin spill similar to the priorities E've been talking a the Beginnig of the onset of Covid.
We included these parities when we passed the Jumpstart progressive revenue proposal back in June and July of last year.
We included them again centering our values around equity and making sure that we were putting funding directly to those most impacted in our budget last year.
These bills in front of us today respond directly to the crises exacerbated by Covid by investing in housing, and homelessness.
Economic resiliency and small businesses.

And to the arts and culture and directly into making sure that those who have been most disproportionately impacted, and often left out of previous Federal assistance under the Trump administration, were first to receive dollars.

That we centered investments, not just in ensuring that those individuals were thought of, but that the organizations are work directly with those individuals and to have trust, and deep ties and roots within those communities, are receiving those dollars.
Is only a few areas that I'll highlight because I know a lot of folks are excited about highlighting various commitments they've included.

One of the things I'm most excited about is $25 million in direct cash assistance specifically to go into the hands of working families and individuals, our Elders and folks that have been really struggling by the impacts of Covid, to make sure that we can have a direct infusion into our local economy.
Recognizing that those who are experiencing hardship know best how to use that cash assistance.

I'm most excited about the Childcare systems of $8 million combined going directly to support Childcare Spiders and $5 million of that going to create greater access to affordable Childcare throughout our city by making sure we have capital investments to build from our affordable Childcare.

In King County and Seattle, we know that somewhere between 7 to 10% of our Childcare facilities have closed, and some looking like they are on foresight going to stay permanently closed unless we do something and act with urgency now as a city council.

We know this is a critical investment for us to make because across our Nation and right here in the city of Seattle, if we don't invest in Childcare, it hurts our local economy, as well as hurting local families.
The closure of Childcare across our country is resulting in billions of dollars lost to employers each year.
And over 500,000 children without Childcare in our country.

Childcare workers have found themselves out of work during this pandemic with a net loss of around 170,000 Childcare worker positions opened between January of 2020 and January of 2021 we can do something about that right here.

Our investment of $8 million into Childcare specifically attempts to make sure that we are encouraging the creation of additional Childcare and recognizing and honoring and appreciating those Childcare providers who have helped us during this last year.
We talked about the need for this rescue plan to respond to the theme session.

Not the recession, recognizing that women were much more likely to have left the workforce because of lack of access to Childcare and also recognizing that it has been disproportionate women and people of color who have been on the frontline more exposed to Covid if they have been able to keep their jobs as a center workers in the service sector in many cases.

I'm really excited about the ways in which we tied in care for the trauma that people have been through in the last year by investing funding into domestic violence prevention, youth services, senior services, to care for isolation and neglect.

I know there's much more we need to do, but I want to also see these investments paired with what the county has offered, King County is investing about $30 million specifically for behavioral health responses and recovery to help identify ways in which we can make sure that those who have been hardest hit, even before Covid, but especially those who have had their behavioral and mental health needs exacerbated during Covid, that they have the services they need.
I want to applaud King County Council and the executive on the passage of their rescue plan act just a few weeks ago.

Our proposal is going to be packaged and complement many of the areas that King County invested in and investments in Dave your health is one area where I'm excited to see the complementary funding streaming go on.

I want to note as I'm sure Councilmember Lewis may speak to, the importance of the five--over $5 million I should say, $7.5 million if I remember from recollection, that is going in to match the King County just cares like program.
Services like Ghesquiere that is responding directly to the need for homeless folks, those experiencing homelessness, to have access to appropriate shelter during the time of Covid.
Recognizing we are not out of the storm yet the Variants continue to show increasing concern in our area.
We want to make sure none Congregant shelter options like hotels are invested in and that we match the county's effort of around $7.5 million to bring programs like just care to scale.

We have said it countless times about the pandemic, we know that the exacerbation of the inequities that were present before have just been made worse by Covid, but those especially Archer for the racial inequities.
We see race of communities of color who have been contracting Covid and dying from Covid.
Be Exponentially higher than white residents.

This pattern follows many other social inequities that put racial and ethnic minorities at increased risk, and increased risk of health disparities, educational attainment disparities, wealth and income gap disparities and so much more.
That's why we have centered our investments today on making sure that we are looking at near and long-term investments for the Seattle rescue plan act through the lens of what is just.

Just for racial and ethnic commitments for making sure that folks have been disproportionately impacted have the assistance they need and that we are creating greater opportunities for economic stability and opportunity.

I'm very excited about the language that we also included that make sure that Community- based organizations are culturally relevant and historically rooted in and funded by communities that have been disproportionately impacted by Covid and have organizational leadership staff.
For the purposes of direct grants and allocations of grants to committees.
We built this language with community partners . is not just important to talk about where the funding goes, but how the funding is allocated.
That language is intentionally written in and expanded actually as well into both this bill and the cash assistance bill that we will pass as a follow-up to this legislation.

With just noting those few areas in my excitement around the $28.5 million going into housing and acquisition and building more homes.

I do want to just talk about a couple of the amendments that were included in this bill.

Our office, after lots of conversation with small business, with arts organizations, grassroots activists, and even other elected officials, worked really hard together their ideas and input on how to use this sort of once in a generation investment.
To build a more equitable economic recovery.
I'm excited to have two amendments that were developed in partnership with them included here.
The kind of conversations we were having included an acknowledgment that there just isn't enough economic opportunity for folks in the city.
46% of the workforce in greater Seattle is either unemployed or stuck in low-wage work before Covid, and we know that problem has only gotten worse.
We know that there is also an inequitable access to opportunity in the city.
Particularly for black and Hispanic folks in our community.
And that Seattle ranks in the bottom third of large Metro areas for black and Hispanic representation in technology and in managerial roles.
So, I'm excited that with this bill we can really begin to address some of these disparities.
The commitment of $22 million into this bill to create good jobs, to begin developing skills that are relevant to good jobs.
Supporting friends with technical assistance.
Increasing access to wealth building strategies.
These are the kinds of investments that we need in order to really begin building an equitable recovery for folks.
The other thing I want to acknowledge is that--and I do want to thank Councilmember Lewis for your comments.

A big, big part of the inequity that we have experienced is because our neighborhood business associations, neighborhood commercial districts, just don't have access to the kind of resources that a downtown area might be able to generate.
I do think it's important that $5.5 million of the funding will be specifically for neighborhood business organizations and associations.
Then, the last thing I want to say is that the bill also addresses, or begins to address the challenges of our young people.
Who are trying to get the skills that they need to have a Pathway to good Union paying--Union wage jobs.

To career paths, and especially for those who maybe taking care of family members or may not have an opportunity to go to college, I'm excited that our office has been working with the court Commission to expand the current opportunity youth initiative by adding $1 million to the existing program.

So, as I mentioned before, an important strategy that can help lead young people into good Union jobs includes expanding Internships . This $1 million will go a long way toward expanding that program, not just for the summer, but expanding it to a year-round program that can really support our young people.
So, I want to thank the members of the Finance and housing Committee for their support of these amendments that I offered.
Look forward to passing a bill that is really rooted in the principles of an equitable recovery.

That were raised by Councilmembers, public Commenters, and Community-Based organizations.

Although $120 million is not sufficient to meet the various critical needs facing our city's residents, we have a unique opportunity with this funding to make a difference in the lives of countless Seattleites and set our city on a path toward a more equitable economic recovery from the Covid-19 public health and economic crises.
I am truly excited about the resources being provided in this legislation to do some of the following.
Expand affordable housing opportunities and homelessness services.
Provide direct support to small businesses, workers and neighborhood commercial districts across the city.
Increase Childcare infrastructure and enhance wages for child care workers.
This infusion of resources will help Home-Based and day care centers reopen, or expand, which will ultimately grow our city's Childcare network and allow parents to get back to work.
We will also invest in the reopening of cultural and arts institutions.
We will reactivate and enhance our public spaces like parks and streets for outdoor recreation, commercial opportunities and socially distanced activities.
And this package offers direct cash assistance to those who have been most impacted by the pandemic.
These critical investments made in the Seattle rescue plan could not be possible without the hard work of our state's congressional delegation as well.
We want to thank them for their efforts in passing the American rescue plan act to begin with.
I am very grateful to our Federal representatives and president Joe Biden for ensuring that these needed resources are made available to local governments, and of course our residents.

Finally, in closing out my comments, I would be Remiss if I didn't acknowledge the fact that had this Council, led by Councilmember Mosqueda and a broad coalition of Stakeholders, had this Council not passed the Jumpstart Seattle progressive payroll tax in 2020, we would not be in a position to be making any of these investments.

Without the roughly $200 million in revenue expected from the Jumpstart Seattle progressive payroll tax, we would have been forced to lay off hundreds of city of Seattle employees and drastically reduce city services.
Without that revenue, we would be using all of the funds from the American rescue plan act to plug holes in the city's budget.
And simply restore spending and services to Pre-Pandemic levels.

Fortunately, thanks to the tremendous work that was done to pass Jumpstart Seattle, and to defend its legality in court, we are in this position today to use these Federal dollars to greatly expand the services and resources our city is able to offer as we look towards rebuilding equitably across our city.

This legislation updates the city's affordable housing funding policy.
It makes some important updates building on the deep changes that were rooted in community needs and suggestions that we took in my committee back in 2019.

Those changes included expanding upon and clarifying the city's intent to use community preference and affirmative marketing policies as a framework of the policy framework for ensuring that those who have been most disproportionately impacted by displacement had a strong opportunity to remain in our city and have access to affordable housing.

At that point we included stronger labor standards to make sure that our new housing that was being built had opportunities for greater labor standards and that we look for opportunities to strengthen our commitment to good living wage jobs as we dealt housing.
Language on that should be forthcoming in a report and other work that we did as well.
We also at that point increased office of housing's acquisition authority up to a cap of $30 million at the time.
A lot of that work that we did in 2019 was really rooted in a number of community Roundtable discussions that we had.
Specifically with Bipoc led housing development groups and communities who are most in need of affordable housing in this city.
With that, Fast-Forward to 2021 this is an opportunity to expand on those changes we made and make some small sort of Tweaks to allow for some of those important policy changes to come to fruition.

This does not include major policy directive changes given that this is a proposal I think that was really Well-Crafted as it was sent to us and included some of the previous work that we had done just two years ago.
Is a few things really excited about in this legislation.

If you haven't had a chance to hear me say this before, this is a really great opportunity to increase the homeownership subsidies to make sure we are adequately funding the construction of permanent affordable homes.
To make sure that are very competitive and hot housing market has actual chance of having competition and being able to have more folks access first time homeownership opportunities.
We are in this legislation removing that cap previously we had upped the cap on the acquisition authority, now we are removing it.

The Office of housing has the authority, where needed, when there is no revenue available, to quickly move and seize opportunities to acquire property for the creation of affordable housing, giving the changing market conditions we are seeing.
Why is this important right now?

If we see Multi-Structures going on the market or derelict buildings that we could be using for affordable housing now, or in the future, we want to be competitive and to bring in more publicly owned housing options.
And create public opportunities for folks to have access to good, affordable housing within the city.
Removing this cap is a smart way for us to make sure that we are Seizing those opportunities.
With the onset of covert we've also seen a huge demand and acquisition.
We built some of the acquisition language into our legislation from last year.
With the money now coming in January of this upcoming year, we will have the chance to spend those dollars.
We just put a portion of the $28.5 million for acquisition and development that you all just voted on, in the Seattle rescue plan act bill.
Acquisition, acquisition, acquisition is the theme of the show when it relates to affordable housing right now.
We have made sure that that is a priority in this plan as well.
There's already several projects that have given notice to the city to apply for acquisition funds directly rooted in community.

Organizations, and communities--community organizations that are working and building affordable housing have already submitted their notice to apply for acquisition funds in this year's notice to apply round.
We know there is more opportunities on the horizon.
Really excited to have these important changes and look forward to having your support.
Just very briefly want to thank Miss Alvarado and her team at the office of housing.
Central staff and my office you have been working closely on getting this legislation ready for us to vote on today.
Hope you will Supportit.
